newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka opposition deputy killed by gunmen.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka opposition deputy killed by gunmen.

text.p: A parliamentary deputy of Sri Lanka's main opposition United National Party (UNP) and five others were killed in an attack by gunmen near eastern Trincomalee town on Sunday, police said.
They said UNP MP Mohammed Moharoof's vehicle was attacked on a stretch of road between Trincomalee and nearby Nilaveli at about 10.30 a.m. (0430 GMT).
The dead included a small child, police said.
No other details were immediately available and police could not identify the gunmen, but UNP sources in the capital Colombo confirmed Moharoof had died in the attack.
Moharoof was the second parliamentary deputy to be killed this month in Trincomalee, 260 km (160 miles) east of Colombo.
Arunasalam Thangathurai, Trincomalee parliamentary deputy for the Tamil United Liberation Front (TULF), died in a grenade attack on July 5.

Thangathurai, who was killed while entering his vehicle after inaugurating a new school building in Trincomalee, was the eighth TULF leader to die in a series of political assassinations in as many years.
Four others, including the school principal, were also killed and 15 were wounded in the July 5 attack.
Police blamed the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) for Thangathurai's killing, but nobody has claimed responsibility for the attack.
The LTTE are fighting a 13-year-old war for an independent homeland for minority Tamils in Sri Lanka's north and east.
The government says more than 50,000 people have been killed in the war. The LTTE puts the toll higher.
